The largest ? Delta IV is only 2 meter taller than Falcon Heavy, but far behind in all other things.

While the Falcon Heavy and the Delta IV Heavy may have similar structural designs, there are two very distinct differences. The first being the Falcon Heavy has three launch cores, each fitted with nine Merlin engines. Whereas the Delta IV Heavy also has three cores, but only one Aerojet Rocketdyne RS-68 engine per core. The second difference is that the Falcon Heavy’s cores can return to earth and are reusable, while the Delta IV Heavy boosters are non-reusable, and fall into the ocean.

With these powerful engines, and both rockets first and second stages, each system can put its payload into Low Earth Orbit (LEO), Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit (GTO), Geosynchronous Orbit (GEO), Lunar Transfer Orbit (LTO), and Mars Transfer orbit. With all stages attached, the Delta IV Heavy stands at 72 m (236 ft) tall and weighs roughly 733,000 kg (1,616,000 lbs) empty. The Falcon Heavy stands at 70 m (229 ft) tall and weighs 1,420,788 kg (3,125,735 lbs). That is close to double the weight of the Delta IV Heavy, but with the power to back it up.

The Falcon Heavy boasts that it can carry an astounding 63,800k g (140,660 lbs) to LEO. This capability is the most massive payload sent to orbit since the Saturn V in 1973. The Delta IV Heavy can carry 22,560 kg (49,740 lbs) to LEO. That’s just a third of what the Falcon Heavy can carry.

The last of the old model launch and throw away which is actually based on missile engineer thinking, which is what the space race was - to legitimize the need to build rockets in the first place.
It took someone like Elon to come along to say, throwing rockets away is ridiculous - and changed the world of space travel based on a new paradigm.
The cost of launches escalated to over USD 400 million per launch as all the defense contractors work on cost plus, so it is not in anyone's interest to keep the launch costs low. There weren't a lot of competitors either. So SpaceX was a real disrupter here, and rightfully so. They are now going to literally build 1000 star ships - i.e. a production line of rockets thereby heralding a true space industry - and we are just at the beginning. Paradigm shifts in breakthrough technologies eventually leading to rendering craft massless and new physics is bound to eventually be discovered so we won't need to burn fuels to launch anymore.
